reviewText: I enjoy the series of Montalbano novels by Camillieri, and it is fun watching the TV series to see what these places look like and absorb the Sicilian mannerisms of the characters. My wife, who has not read the books, has enjoyed the series as well. There is a light-hearted slant that keeps these episodes from being as dark as they might. Each episode is one novel and takes about 1 1/2 hours. These episodes adhere pretty closely to the books. My only gripe is that the subtitles skip some of the dialogue. However, sometimes when all the dialogue is covered, you have to read fast to keep up with the torrent of Italian syllables. Having seen episodes 1-6, I look forward to seeing more Montalbano.

reviewText: Set in Sicily, Italy, and based on a series of novels, INSPECTOR MONTALBANO has proved successful in various parts of Europe. I caught it on BBC4, the cultural channel of the BBC. It takes a lot to infuse what might be termed an over-familiar genre with touches of originality, but INSPECTOR MONTALBANO achieves this task successfully. This is chiefly due to the interplay between the three main characters (Luca Zingaretti, Angelo Russo, Cesare Bocci), who work successfully as a team yet continually bicker with one another. The shooting-style also helps; there is an extensive use of outdoor locations - as opposed to the uniformly gray interior sequences of many British detective series - and a greater reliance on pans and zooms, rather than shot/reverse shots. This gives the series an epic feel, despite the familiarity of the story lines. The scripts are tautly written with plenty of opportunities for throwaway lines from the main protagonists. Definitely worth a look as a refreshing alternative to Anglo-American detective series.
summary: Slickly Made Detective Series with a Fair Infusion of Humor
Title: N/A

reviewText: I have not had the pleasure of reading the detective stories on which these films are based, but I have lived nine years in Italy, and I love the Montalbano films, not only for their peculiar Italian--all right, Sicilian--sense of humor, but also for their cracking good mysteries. Filmed on the spot in Sicily, they are feasts for the eyes, as well as for the appetite, since almost every episode features delectable dishes on which Montalbano dines with zest. And living in Montalbano's seafront palazzo would not be bad either!I can understand why some viewers are frustrated at the speed of the subtitles, because I can barely keep up with them to catch the Sicilian dialect (but their speedy appearance and disappearance forces me to listen to the language, which seems fired at the speed of a bullet, and to pick up new expressions, some of the saltier of which have been watered down in translation!).Montalbano may not be the typical handsome hero, but his kind disposition compensates for any lack of conventional looks ("The Snack Thief" is a particularly heartwarming episode, in which we meet the elusive Livia, who spends most of her time telephoning from Genova). His colleagues at the -polizia- are great fun; always at the heart of some chaotic -pasticcio-, they are anything but conventional and by no means boring.Commissario Montalbano is a welcome addition to one's collection of foreign mystery DVDs, especially if one has lived or traveled in Italy and Sicily. The stories are so engaging that they can be enjoyed over and over -con molto piacere-!
summary: A Series that Delights the Eye and Whets the Appetite!

Italian is a beautiful language, but toomuchtoofast...Usually I love to listen to the music of other languages.  I often watch subtitled movies and I do not find subtitles distracting.  I was disappointed that I didn't want to watch this.  I tried to trade it in on amazon, but they said it was the wrong URL number and wouldn't accept it.  That's a mystery since it was the dvd I had just purchased from amazon.

reviewText: At first the sub-titles were a little disconcerting but I got used to it quickly. The settings and the plot are excellent and the actors are a joy to watch. I had only previously read "The Shape of Water" (the third DVD in this first series) and I found the DVD followed the plot of the book with the added joy of watching a setting I have never visited.  The detective novel "The Shape of Water"  seemed very "wordy" to me while the DVD sub titles went to the heart of the matter. Again watching the supporting actors (like the "wronged" wife in DVD #2) was also real pleasure.  The sub-plot involving Livia ties the separate plots together and gives a real humanity to the Detective that other detective plots often lack. Anyway,  this is not Ho-Hum viewing. If you are up for an adventure, go for this  Detective.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I thought I'd like this one, even though the skinhead, stocky, bandy-legged actor who plays Montalbano seems to be given the lines of a typical Italian movie cliche bachelor playboy.  The scenery's nice, but I keep wondering how a policeman can afford that seafront house with a balcony.  Hmmm?  I also note that many of the plots end up with some vamping beautiful woman committing the crime.  Sexism?  In Italy?? Ho hum.The whole thing doesn't wear well, but I might have kept watching since some moments are sensitive and well played, except for one of the worst miscastings in film history.  There's an actor with a smoker's voice playing a bumbling cop who salutes incessantly and trips over his own feet.  I don't know his name.  He's supposed to be funny, but the over-acted portrayal irritates me beyond belief.  In fact, "belief" is the trouble.  A clumsy clown like this guy wouldn't even have made it out of Cop School, probably not even INTO Cop School, so I can't believe him.  He ruins the series and I've stopped watching.

reviewText: This series, even with subtitles, is better than any other police procedural TV series that I have ever seen.  The best part about it is the introduction of a fun relationship between Montalbano and his crew of cops.
summary: Better than any other police series on TV
Title: N/A

reviewText: In frustration after the wonderful Rufus Sewell Zen series was cut short, my spouse and I looked to see if there was anything similar and found these.  How did we not know about them before? The stories are complex and specific to Sicily, and the characters and settings are unique.  As someone else mentioned, the plots follow the original novels very faithfully, yet bring everything alive, and then some.  The Sicilian locations could not be more authentic or gorgeous, Montalbano himself is very charismatic, the acting is fabulous, and it is all in Italian, or Sicilian -- it is just too fast to know!!! If you love words, you'll love this. There are so very many words! There is also humor, and food, which Montalbano deeply appreciates.  We've already enjoyed some do-it-yourself Sicilian cookery in appreciation (pasta with broccoli, raisins, sardines, and pine nuts, Montalbano's favorite dish).

reviewText: Hands down Detective Montalbano is one of my favorite shows of all time.  Luca Zingaretti's acting is just fantastic, I just love this guy. He doesn't have to say a word and conveys so much.  The entire crew is excellent and fun to watch.  The music, the stories, the setting, all of it.  I have never been one for subtitles but this show holds my interest.  It is actually nice, I sit and watch instead of multi-tasking like I do when watching American shows.

reviewText: Having read all of the translated versions of the Montalbano series, and knowing that there were movies of the stories shown on RAI, it was great to finally have the DVDs available in western format. After viewing the first three stories, it was well worth the wait--the cast is perfect and the scripts do complete justice to Mr. Camilleri's writing.  Now we're looking forward to seeing the full set of the DVDs.  Highly recommend them to Inspector Montalbano's many fans.
summary: Authentic DVD Versions of the Books

reviewText: I read all the books first, and while some are better than others, it's an enjoyable series.  I did notice after about five books that there was no reason for Montalbano and Olivia to be together, and for so many years.  Then when the DVD's became available, I thought how great!  And I bought the first disk to see if I'd like the stories as films.  They are well done, very true to the books, but they do point out even more clearly how awful his girlfriend is.  She's just not a believable person, in my opinion, and pretty unlikeable in the series.  I wish the author would replace her somehow.  She's the worst part of an otherwise unique set of stories.
summary: Great on DVD, great books, horrible girlfriend

reviewText: We are introduced to Inspector Salvo Montalbano, who works in the fictional town of "Vigàta", in the equally fictional district of "Montelusa" in Scilly. Where the Sun is bright and life treads at a different pace, amongst classic bleached white villages and towns that would look out of place in a tourist guide book. In this almost Mediterranean idle there is darkness,decay and at times murder.He and the members of Vigata's small police force, namely Mimì Augello, Montalbano's second-in-charge, Fazio, Gallo, Galluzzo and the incredibly stupid yet very likeable Catarella, who mans the station's phones, among other minor tasks. While his whole team have suffered from his out bursts, and sometime strange management style he cares for them and in turn they are all very loyal to him, none more so than his girlfriend of 8 plus years. Salvo is a foodie, with a passion, and he rarely permits anything to get between him and good meal,including other social commitments. He is also an avid swimmer, so much so, his apartment is set on the beach front.Luca Zingaretti who plays the major role really brings the detective to life; his characterisation for me is spot on. His case work always varied, and never what you would expect to happen happens - there are red herrings and misdirection!In Salvo's work nothing is black and white; mainly his cases are in the grey zone. As one reviewer put it his cases do not have happy endings, while his investigations sometimes leads to organized crime, his stories rarely get totally focused on the Mafia rather they are part of the landscape and environment of where he works in and around.The last few years have seen a plethora of foreign defective series from around Europe each series of any real credit brings fresh cultural nuances, behaviour and identity of their own. After years of British and American detective series these shows, are like a new revelation. While some may hate subtitles I can assure you that to see and hear these shows as they were originally broadcast is always best and I find them all the more enjoyable.My only minor gripe was the extras seemed too `light', and I also thought there would have been more episodes on the discs.If you like detective stories then this series are not to be missed

reviewText: One of the problems I find with books that are made into movies is that the directors and writers seldom remember the original plot, let alone the place and pace of the characters, which is happily not the case with this DVD series. The filming, plotlines and casting in these first three episodes are spot on and although it takes a little time to get used to the quick subtitles this, my friends, is very good entertainment and well worth the price. Luca Zingaretti in the lead role of Inspector (Detective) Montalbano is one of the best detectives you'll find on the big (or little) screen today and Zingaretti and the great cast of actors and Sicilian locations make it happen with convincing style. Zingaretti is Montalbano to the proverbial T and producer Carlo Degli Esposti and director Alberto Sironi have captured the heart, sweat and soul of Andrea Camilleri's three books; The Snack Thief, The Voice of the Violin and The Shape of Water that you'll find on these initial disks. Although one reviewer complained about the fast pace of the subtitles, I found it to be convincing enough since it falls in line with most Italian speakers I know and any conversations I tried in Italy.The subtitle pace annoyed me initially too until I realized it matched the actual speech patterns. Then I chuckled. Besides, with DVDs what we miss, we can always go back and pick up with the rewind.I've spent the last year turning some friends on to Camilleri's works because they're just well written and enjoyable so now I'll champion this DVD series for the same reasons. These are anything but the same old plots or whudunnit mysteries.Buy the books and buy the DVD collection. This is Italian (Sicilian) gold and friends, it shines!Will other reviewers agree with me? Probably not because like most of us, what we read we envision in our mind's eye and form our own interpretations. We all occasionally wear rose colored glasses which might explain love, folks who believe pug dogs are cute, and probably our reviews here.
Title: N/A
